OUTSTANDING GAME My favourite RPG of all time. Story and dialogue still hold up. Incredible music, especially the main theme. Rydia and Cecil among all-time great ff protagonists, with Kain providing the classic hubris. Golbez an underrated villain. No major control problems, but the camera seemed slightly too zoomed in for interior areas. Drop rates are unbelievably low for rare items near the end (will those flan princesses ever give me a pink tail?), encounter rates are high, and the game should do a better job of explaining the abilities system (many abilities are only received if other abilities are distributed in a specific way, and repercussions of poor ability distribution can extend even to 2nd and 3rd playthroughs, though this is not made clear to the player), but it's all very much worth it. An undeniable classic and a worthy port.

As a console gamer, I was skeptical at first to play a Final Fantasy game on a smartphone. This FFIV port shattered that skepticism. The on screen controls are surprisingly smooth and the auto battle feature is great for level grinding. I enjoyed the 3D graphical remake of the classic 16-bit FFIV. The character portrayals were refreshing and the voice-acted cutscenes were great. The only gripe I had was it is a bit more difficult to play a console-grade game on a smartphone screen for long stretches of time without having to take more frequent breaks to rest my arms and hands (Galaxy S7 Edge user here.) Gamepad support in the future would help alleviate this issue for people craving a marathon gaming experience. Screen mirroring to a TV makes for a more immersive console-like cutscene and dialogue experience, but the input lag to TV makes actual gameplay this way impractical. All in all, this is a solid app worth every penny (or gil?) that delivers a genuine Final Fantasy experience wherever you happen to be.

After pounding in over 100 hours in this game, I feel it is ready for a review. Story: The story was fun and exciting. Enough so to keep me playing through it 2 more times after I beat it the first. It was awesome watching some of the characters develop, including the antagonist from the beginning. After the credits roll, I felt happy that I was able to experience a story like this. Controls: the controls definitely take some time to get used to. The best part is being able to put your finger anywhere to start moving. In battles it's not super smooth with what you try to press, but you can usually work with it. Sometimes you will try to scroll down or try to select a different hero and accidentally use a command. Graphics: graphically, there were no issues running on my Droid Turbo. The game ran really well with no fps lag or skews and on top of that, it looked really pretty compared to the old SNES version in my opinion.  Final notes:  There were a lot of things I liked about this game. Including the difficult optional bosses and even the optional dungeons that made me play even longer. I liked the cutscenes and voices for the characters as well. It really helped to make the story feel more alive.  Overall: This game was a fantastic play. I would recommend it if you are into role playing games. I rate this 4.8/5.

As for the game itself, this is easily my favorite in the franchise, and the DS/iOS/Android port is probably the nicest, most modern port yet. I'd love to see the bonus dungeons and character swapping of the GBA rather than the augments from the DS, but that doesn't prevent this from being one of the best games on Android yet. The addition of achievements is nice, if jarring (this is the first game I've played on my phone or tablet with achievements, so it was strange to see them pop up; stranger still in the middle of a game I've played hundreds of times on other platforms).  Overall, A+ game. Definitely worth the (admittedly hefty) purchase price.

This only changes the difficulty of the enemies, which I gladly chose hard to make it more challenging, and it's DEFINITELY challenging! Originally for the SNES, this 3D remake is awesome.  On my Samsung Galaxy Note II, it runs perfectly.  The graphics are simple yet totally clean, with no detail left out.  Also has a widescreen option for the big boys.  The cutscenes have voiceover and updated dialog, improving character development and making for a more engaging storyline that already starts out with a lot of twist and turns.  In respect to the original, it is basically a map by map remake so far (I have only been playing for several hours).  The story also follows the original identically.  If it stays that way, you are looking at many hours of gameplay, with many towns, dungeons, and worlds to explore.  The only thing that I would add an option for is the size of the motion circle; it would be easier to navigate the maps if it was a little tighter.  With my huge screen, I have to drag my thumb across a lot of space, and it gets annoying and is less precise.  But I would put up with a lot to play this game in all of it's glory!
